name: Albertson conjecture
summary: The Albertson conjecture is an unsubstantiated connection between a graph's chromatic number and crossing number in combinatorial mathematics. It is named after Smith College professor Michael O. Albertson, who made it a hypothesis in 2007;[1] it is one of his many graph coloring theory conjectures.[2] According to the conjecture, the complete graph {\displaystyle K_{n}} has the shortest crossing number out of all the graphs that require {\displaystyle n} colors. The conjecture states that a graph may have fewer colors than {\displaystyle n} if it can be constructed with fewer crossings than {\displaystyle K_{n}}.
